content:
Please recheck examples from the statement: it is said that "97.98.26992" is translated into "abcd.com", but instead is translated into "abip.com". This is the second ip address in the first row; and I didn't find any other faulty examples.

Also the given description of class B / class A addresses is very confusing -- it is easy to think that CD means C and D concatenated, like 99.100 -> 99100.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Historical IP addresses took me a while until I remembered bit shifting. Great idea
This was pretty fun! I could see it becoming a good challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: very good exercise to practice ip translation

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As already mentioned in my comment a few days ago ;-) !

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement.

Thanks.

Inspired by the following post on the open social web (or fediverse):
https://mastodon.gougere.fr/@bortzmeyer/111827255449113621

Used the following to make my test cases:

```
>>> def f(x):b=bytes(map(ord, x));print('.'.join(map(str, b)));print('.'.join(map(str, b[:2])) + '.' + str(int.from_bytes(b[2:], 'big')));print(str(b[0]) + '.' + str(int.from_bytes(b[1:], 'big')))
... 
>>> f('abcd')
97.98.99.100
97.98.25444
97.6447972
```

Hi, well done, it's a really good idea to normalize the IP address into an integer instead of into a list of four integers like I do, especially if you lack good iteration operators! In fact, that's pretty much how it's done in historical IPv4 implementations :-)

Hi, you're absolutely right for the example, nice catch, thanks! It was in the test cases as well, so the correct example was "97.98.25444".

Also, ok for the formats, I've just put "A.B.C" and "A.B" in the hopes that it makes the statement more clear! :-)
Thanks for your reply & changes! I think the description is clearer now :)
